newsitem.title: USA: First Boston ups Brazil stocks, cuts Mexico.
newsitem.headline: First Boston ups Brazil stocks, cuts Mexico.

text.p: CS First Boston said on Tuesday it had upgraded Brazilian stocks to overweight from neutral in its model portfolio of Latin American shares.
The firm said in a report it was cutting Mexican equities from overweight to slight underweight.
Brazilian stocks were increased to 48 from 43 percent in the portfolio and Mexico fell to 23 from 28 percent, analysts Stefano Natella and James Upton wrote in a report.
"We estimate the upside in Brazilian equities to be around 15 percent by year-end 1996 (Bovespa equivalent of $27.50) and 30-40 percent more by year-end 1997 (Bovespa equivalent of $37)," they wrote.

"For Mexico, we are projecting a seven percent upside in U.S. dollars from now until year end" with the Mexican stock exchange index at 3,650 and the monetary exchange rate at eight pesos to the dollar "and an additional 10-20 percent in 1997" with the index at 4,700 and the exchange rate at nine pesos to the dollar.
